sen.j: 出納（すいのう）は、蔵人所の職員の1つで蔵人所の財物の出納をはじめ、一切の庶務を掌った。
sen.e: Suino was the officer of Kurodo dokoro (the Office of Imperial Household Logistics) and was in charge of all of general affaires including the receipts and disbursement of the treasury of Kurodo dokoro.

Suino was the officer of Kurodo dokoro (the Office of Imperial Household Logistics) and was in charge of all of general affaires including the receipts and disbursement of the treasury of Kurodo dokoro.
Suino was the officer of Kurododokoro (the Chamberlain's Office) and was in charge of all of general affaires including the receipts and disbursement of the treasury of Kurododokoro.
sen.cmt: 用語集に合わせました。

sen.j: 江戸時代には蔵人方地下人を統括して地下家官人としては、弁官局局務・太政官官務とともに「催官人」と呼ばれた。
sen.e: In the Edo period, Suino oversaw the jigenin (court officials who were not allowed the access to the palace) of Kurodogata (anothr name of Kurodo dokoro), and as jigekekanjin (officials came from the families which were not allowed to enter the palace), he was called "Saikanjin" along with Kyokumu (the chief secretary) of Benkankyoku (Controllers' Office) and Kanmu (chief secretary) of Daijokan (Grand Council of State).

In the Edo period, Suino oversaw the jigenin (court officials who were not allowed access to the palace) of Kurodogata (another name for Kurodo dokoro), and as jigekekanjin (officials came from the families which were not allowed to enter the palace), he was called "Saikanjin" along with Kyokumu (the chief secretary) of Benkankyoku (Controllers' Office) and Kanmu (chief secretary) of Daijokan (Grand Council of State).

In the Edo period, Suino oversaw the jigenin (court officials who were not allowed access to the palace) of Kurodogata (another name for Kurododokoro), and as Jigekekanjin (officials came from the families which were not allowed to enter the palace), he was called 'Saikanjin' along with Kyokumu (the chief secretary) of Benkankyoku (Controllers' Office) and Kanmu (chief secretary) of Daijokan (Grand Council of State).
sen.cmt: 前出表記に合わせました。

sen.j: 平安時代には定員3名で蔵人所における出納業務を行ったほか、蔵人所が出す牒・下文・返抄などの文書を蔵人に代わって起草・作成して蔵人とともに連署した。
sen.e: The prescribed number of personnel for this post was three in the Heian period and in addition to the receipts and disbursements job of Kurodo dokoro, Suino also drafted the documents of Kurodo dokoro, such as cho (official certificate), kudashibumi (document isued by a superior or offoce) and hensho (letter of receipts), and signed these documents together with Kurodo (Chamberlain).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外処理
sen.e: The prescribed number of personnel for this post was three during the Heian period and in addition to the receipts and disbursements jobs for Kurodo dokoro, Suino also drafted the documents of Kurodo dokoro, such as cho (official certificate), kudashibumi (document isued by a superior or offoce) and hensho (letter of receipts), and signed these documents together with Kurodo (Chamberlain).

The prescribed number of personnel for this post was three during the Heian period and in addition to the receipts and disbursements jobs for Kurododokoro, Suino also drafted the documents of Kurododokoro, such as cho (official certificate), kudashibumi (document issued by a superior or office) and hensho (letter of receipts), and signed these documents together with Kurodo (Chamberlain).
sen.cmt: 前出表記に合わせ、スペル修正しました。

sen.j: 学識と事務能力を必要とされ、明法道出身者や官司の事務官出身者が任じられることが多かった。
sen.e: Since knowledge and the ability of clerical work are required for this post, persons who learned myobodo (study of Codes) or experienced civil officers of government office were usually appointed to this position.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外処理
sen.e: Since the knowledge and skill of clerical work are required for this post, persons who learned myobodo (study of Codes) or experienced civil officers in government offices were usually appointed to this position.

Since the knowledge and skill of clerical work are required for this post, persons who learned Myobodo (study of Codes) or experienced civil officers in government offices were usually appointed to this position.

sen.j: また要人などからの推挙も多かった。
sen.e: Also, persons who were recommended by influential persons were often nominated.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外処理
sen.e: Also, persons who were recommended by influential persons were often nominated.
Also, persons who were recommended by influential persons were often nominated.

sen.j: 宇多天皇は退位後に自己の在位中の出納を後院の主典代に任じて事務にあたらせており、天皇とも密接なつながりがあった。
sen.e: After his abdication, the Emperor Uda ordered the secretary of Goin Palace to compile the records of disbursement while he was on the throne, and as seen from this fact, Suino had a close relation with the emperor.

After his abdication, the Emperor Uda ordered the secretary of Goin Palace to compile records of disbursement while he was on the throne, and as seen from this fact, Suino had a close relation with the emperor.

After his abdication, the Emperor Uda ordered the secretary of Goin Palace to compile records of disbursement while he was on the throne, and as seen from this fact, Suino had a close relation with the emperor.

sen.j: ところが、堀河天皇の頃から蔵人に代わって出納が全てを取り仕切り「僭上」とみなされて掣肘が加えられた。
sen.e: In the era of the Emperor Horikawa, however, Suino were under restraint because they were regarded as arrogant since they presided over everything instead of Kurodo.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外処理
sen.e: During the era of Emperor Horikawa, however, Suino were under restraint since they were regarded as arrogant since they presided over everything instead of Kurodo.
During the era of Emperor Horikawa, however, Suino were under restraint since they were regarded as 'arrogant' since they presided over everything instead of Kurodo.
sen.cmt: クォーテーションを補足しました。

sen.j: 以後、雑掌的な業務に限定され、地下人が任じられる地位となった。
sen.e: Since then, Suino's jobs were restricted to miscellaneous ones and the position became the one to which jigenin were appointed.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外処理
sen.e: Since then, the Sunino family was restricted to being placed in mscellaneous jobs and jigenin were appointed to the position.
Since then, the Suino family was restricted to being placed in miscellaneous jobs and jigenin were appointed to the position.

sen.j: 平安時代末期以後は中原氏流の平田家が多く任命されるようになり、途中阿倍氏など他氏が任命されることもあったものの、中世後期に入ると平田家による世襲が確立した。
sen.e: Since the end of Heian period, persons of Hirata family of the Nakahara clan line were often appointed to this post, and in the late stage of medieval times, this post became the hereditary post of Hirata family, though some persons of other families such as the Abe family were appointed in the meantime.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外処理
sen.e: Since the end of Heian period, persons from the Hirata family of the Nakahara clan line were often appointed to this post, and in the late stages of the medieval times, this post became a hereditary post of the Hirata family, though some persons of other families such as the Abe family were appointed in the meantime.

Since the end of Heian period, persons from the Hirata family of the Nakahara clan line were often appointed to this post, and in the late stages of the medieval times, this post became a hereditary post of the Hirata family, though some persons of other families such as the Abe family were appointed in the meantime.

sen.j: 平田家は明治維新まで世襲することとなった。
sen.e: Persons of the Hirata family inherited the post until the Meiji Restoration.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外処理
sen.e: Persons of the Hirata family inherited the post until the Meiji Restoration.
Persons of the Hirata family inherited the post until the Meiji Restoration.

sen.j: 一旦は職掌の多くを奪われた出納であったが、朝廷機構の衰微に伴い出納が蔵人所の職務を再び行うようになった。
sen.e: Suino, who was once deprived of many jobs, resumed doing jobs of Kurodo dokoro with the decline of the structure of the Imperial court.
Suino, who was once deprived of many jobs, resumed doing jobs of Kurodo dokoro together with the decline of the structure of the Imperial court.
Suino, who were once deprived of many jobs, resumed doing jobs of Kurododokoro together with the decline of the structure of the Imperial court.
sen.cmt: 前出表記に合わせ、複数形にしました。

sen.j: 『禁秘抄』には、「蔵人方一切奉行」と記され、蔵人所の運営の実務面で大きな役割を果たしたことが記され、朝廷の各方面に関わるようになる。
sen.e: As "Kinpisho" described Suino as "Kurodogata Issaibugyo" (the head of Kurodogata), Suino played a big role in the management of Kurodo dokoro and was involved in many jobs at the Imperial court.
As "Kinpisho" described Suino as "Kurodogata Issaibugyo" (the head of Kurodogata), Suino played a big role in the management of Kurodo dokoro and was involved in many jobs at the Imperial court.

As "Kinpisho" (a book written by Emperor Juntoku, which records the history and origin of imperial court ceremonies and sets forth the rules and etiquette for carrying out such ceremonies) described Suino as 'Kurodogata Issaibugyo' (the head of Kurodogata), Suino played a big role in the management of Kurododokoro and was involved in many jobs at the Imperial court.
sen.cmt: 補足し、前出表記に合わせました。

sen.j: 平田職忠は舟橋秀賢を学び、有職故実大家として知られ、後陽成天皇にその才能を寵愛され、地下官人では異例の院昇殿が認められた。
sen.e: Oritada HIRATA, who studied Hidetaka FUNABASHI and was known as the expert of Yusoku kojitsu (court and samurai rules on ceremonies and rites), was appreciated by the Emperor Goyozei for his talent and was allowed the access to the retired emperor's palace, though it was a rare case for jigekanjin.

Oritada HIRATA, who studied Hidetaka FUNABASHI and was known as the expert of Yusoku kojitsu (court and samurai rules on ceremonies and rites), was appreciated by the Emperor Goyozei for his talent and was allowed access to the retired emperor's palace, though it was a rare case for jigekanjin.

Oritada HIRATA, who studied Hidetaka FUNABASHI and was known as the expert of Yusoku kojitsu (court and samurai rules on ceremonies and rites), was appreciated by the Emperor Goyozei for his talent and was allowed access to the retired emperor's palace, though it was a rare case for jigekanjin.

sen.j: その頃成立したばかりの江戸幕府は朝廷秩序の回復に関与することで朝廷の統制を行うことを意図していた。
sen.e: The Edo bakufu, which was just established at the time, intended to cotrol the Imperial court by engaging in the restoration of the well-ordered Imperial court.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外処理
sen.e: The Edo bakufu, which had just been established at the time, intended to cotrol the Imperial court by engaging in the restoration of the well-ordered Imperial court.

The Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun), which had just been established at the time, intended to control the Imperial court by engaging in the restoration of the well-ordered Imperial court.
sen.cmt: スペル修正し、補足しました。

sen.j: 朝廷儀式の再興を望む朝廷側との思惑の合致に伴い、地下官人制度の再編が行われた。
sen.e: Such intention of bakufu coincided with the Imperial court's intention to restore Imperial ceremonies, and the system of jigekanjin was revised accordingly.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外処理
sen.e: The intentions by the bakufu coincided with the Imperial court's intention to restore Imperial ceremonies, and the system of jigekanjin was revised accordingly.
The intentions by the bakufu coincided with the Imperial court's intention to restore Imperial ceremonies, and the system of jigekanjin was revised accordingly.

sen.j: その結果、局務押小路家が外記方、官務壬生家が官方、そして出納平田家が蔵人方の地下官人を統率して奉行・職事の指示に従って傘下の地下官人を率いて儀式のために必要な事務・雑務を行うことになった（「禁中諸政諸司等作法事」）。
sen.e: As a result, Kyokumu Oshikoji family, Kanmu Mibu family and Suino Hirata family became responsible for various clerical/administrative jobs relating to ceremonies under the instruction of bugyo/shikiji (the head of office) while commanding the jigekanjin of Gekikata (Secretaries' Office), Kangata (one of government office) and Kurodogata respectively ("Kinchu shoseishojito sahogoto")
sen.cmt: 「禁中諸政諸司等作法事」→読み不明
sen.e: As a result, Kyokumu Oshikoji family, Kanmu Mibu family and Suino Hirata family became responsible for various clerical/administrative jobs relating to ceremonies under the instruction of bugyo/shikiji (the head of office) while commanding the jigekanjin of Gekikata (Secretaries' Office), Kangata (one of government office) and Kurodogata respectively ("Kinchu shoseishojito sahogoto")

As a result, Kyokumu Oshikoji family, Kanmu Mibu family and Suino Hirata family became responsible for various clerical and administrative jobs relating to ceremonies under the instruction of bugyo and shikiji (the head of office) while commanding the jigekanjin of Gekikata (Secretaries' Office), Kangata (one of government office) and Kurodogata respectively ('Kinchu Shosei Shoshi to Sahonokoto' (manners in political affairs and officers of the Imperial Court)).

sen.j: この結果、出納は蔵人所以外の図書寮や主水司、内蔵寮など約60家の地下官人を管轄することになった。
sen.e: As a result, Suino came to control the jigekanjin of about 60 families, including those of Zushoryo (Bureau of Drawings and Books), Mondo no tsukasa (Water Office) and Kuraryo (Bureau of Palace Storehouses), in addition to those of Kurodo dokoro.

As a result, Suino came to control the jigekanjin of about 60 families, including those of Zushoryo (Bureau of Drawings and Books), Mondo no tsukasa (Water Office) and Kuraryo (Bureau of Palace Storehouses), in addition to those of Kurodo dokoro.

As a result, Suino came to control the jigekanjin of about 60 families, including those of Zushoryo (Bureau of Drawings and Books), Mondo no tsukasa (Water Office) and Kuraryo (Bureau of Palace Storehouses), in addition to those of Kurodo dokoro.

sen.j: また、これに伴い平田家の知行高が31石余りに引き上げられて、地下家第3位の地位に上昇した。
sen.e: Also, chigyodaka (a stipend in terms of the rice production of the fief) of the Hirata family was raised to 31 koku (about 5,580 liter) and it became the third-ranking jige family.
Also, chigyodaka (a stipend in terms of the rice production of the fief) of the Hirata family was raised to 31 koku (about 5,580 liter) and it became the third-ranking jige family.
Also, chigyodaka (a stipend in terms of the rice production of the fief) of the Hirata family was raised to 31 koku (about 5,580 liter) and it became the third-ranking jige family.

sen.j: これは、長年「両局」「地下官人之棟梁」と称せられ、地下官人の支配を一手に引き受けてきた局務押小路家・官務壬生家による地下官人に対する独占的支配を抑制して、朝廷の再興と運営効率化を図りたいとする江戸幕府と朝廷上層部の思惑があったと言われている。
sen.e: Behind the above reform, there seems to have been the intention of bakufu and high-ranking people of the Imperial court to restore the Imperial court and realize its effective management by restricting the monopolistic rule over jigekanjin by Kyokumu Oshikoji family and Kanmu Mibu family, which exclusively ruled jigekanjin for a long period and were called "Ryokyoku" or "the leader of jigekanjin".

Behind the scenes of the above reform, the bakufu and high-ranking people of the Imperial court seemed intent to restore the Imperial court and realize its effective management by restricting the monopolistic rule over jigekanjin by Kyokumu Oshikoji family and Kanmu Mibu family, which exclusively ruled jigekanjin for a long period and were called "Ryokyoku" or "the leader of jigekanjin".

Behind the scenes of the above reform, the bakufu and high-ranking people of the Imperial court seemed intent to restore the Imperial court and realize its effective management by restricting the monopolistic rule over jigekanjin by Kyokumu Oshikoji family and Kanmu Mibu family, which exclusively ruled jigekanjin for a long period and were called 'Ryokyoku' or 'the leader of jigekanjin.'
sen.cmt: クォーテーションを変えました。

sen.j: 以後、局務・官務・出納はそれぞれの管轄下の地下官人を統率する催官人としてその地位を世襲した。
sen.e: Since then, the posts of Kyokumu, Kanmu and Suino became hereditary posts, and persons appointed to these posts were called Saikanjin who were supposed to command jigekanjin under their respective jurisdiction.

Since then, the posts of Kyokumu, Kanmu and Suino became hereditary posts, and persons appointed to these posts were called Saikanjin who were supposed to command jigekanjin under their respective jurisdiction.

Since then, the posts of Kyokumu, Kanmu and Suino became hereditary posts, and persons appointed to these posts were called Saikanjin who were supposed to command jigekanjin under their respective jurisdiction.

sen.j: ただし、待遇において出納平田家は職掌面では、「両局」と称せられた局務押小路家・官務壬生家よりも格下の扱いを受けた。
sen.e: In terms of treatment, however, the Hirata family was treated as a family that was inferior to Kyokumu Oshikoji family and Kanmu Mibu family which were called "Ryokyoku".
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外処理 「両局」→読み、定訳不明
sen.e: In terms of treatment, however, the Hirata family was treated as a family that was inferior to Kyokumu Oshikoji family and Kanmu Mibu family which were called "Ryokyoku".
In terms of treatment, however, the Hirata family was treated as a family that was inferior to Kyokumu Oshikoji family and Kanmu Mibu family which were called 'Ryokyoku.'
sen.cmt: クォーテーションを変えました。

sen.j: 押小路家・壬生両家は明治維新後は男爵に叙せられたのに対して、平田家はその他の官人と同様の士族として扱われた。
sen.e: After the Meiji Restoration, while both families of Oshikoji and Mibu were conferred Baron, the Hirata family was treated as shizoku (family with samurai ancestors) equally with other government officials.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外処理
sen.e: After the Meiji Restoration, while both families of Oshikoji and Mibu were conferred Baron, the Hirata family was treated as shizoku (family with samurai ancestors) equally with other government officials.

After the Meiji Restoration, while both Oshikoji and Mibu families were conferred Baron, the Hirata family was treated as shizoku (family with samurai ancestors) equally with other government officials.

sen.j: とは言え、地下官人としての出納の地位は実務面においては局務・官務とほぼ同様の権限を有していた。
sen.e: Being jigekanjin, however, Suino's authority in practical jobs was equivalent to that of Kyokumu and Kanmu.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外処理
sen.e: Being jigekanjin, however, Suino's authority in practical jobs was equivalent to that of Kyokumu and Kanmu.
Being jigekanjin, however, Suino's authority in practical jobs was equivalent to that of Kyokumu and Kanmu.

sen.j: 今日の近世朝廷研究ではこの時期の地下官人を局務・官務・出納の催官人3家によって統率された「三催」体制であったとされている。
sen.e: At present, a common view of the researchers of the early-modern times Imperial court is that the status of jigekanjin at that time was "Sansai" structue led by the three Saikanjin families of Kyokumu, Kanmu and Suino.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外処理 「三催」→読み、定訳不明
sen.e: At present, a common view of the researchers of the early-modern times Imperial court is that the status of jigekanjin at that time was "Sansai" structue led by the three Saikanjin families of Kyokumu, Kanmu and Suino.

At present, a common view of the researchers of the early-modern times Imperial court is that the status of jigekanjin at that time was 'Sansai' (literally, three officials) structure led by the three Saikanjin families of Kyokumu, Kanmu and Suino.
sen.cmt: スペル修正し、補足しました。
